author: sfgate.com
title: Retailers might find holidays less jolly this year
text:
Retailers are in for a somewhat less merry holiday season this year, according to a forecast by consultants at Deloitte who predict a 3.5 to 4 percent increase in sales during the industry’s most crucial selling period, compared with a 5.2 percent rise in 2014.
While more people have jobs, home values have increased and gas prices have remained low, Deloitte’s retail practice leader, Rod Sides , said shoppers still do not feel they have disposable income to burn.
“From a retail perspective, the first couple quarters of the year were pretty tough, and we’re just starting to see that turn the corner,” Sides said. “So I think what happens is there’s a little bit of a lingering effect in terms of how people are feeling ... about how much they can go spend.”
Deloitte predicts that total sales for retailers — excluding the motor vehicle and gasoline categories — will be between $961 billion and $965 billion from November to January.
Deloitte expects a stronger sales increase in the online shopping category, 8.5 to 9 percent. Sides said that this figure might be a little lower than some analysts expected, but it reflects the way customers shift between online and brick-and-mortar shopping. Many shoppers, for example, are taking advantage of “buy online, pick up in store” options, while plenty of others are researching a purchase online but actually buy it later in the store.
“We’re finding that those lines are blurring, and I think this is just now retail business as normal,” Sides said.
So while the digital channel continues to be of critical importance to retailers, the number of shoppers actually closing the deal online might not be growing as rapidly as expected.
In recent years, the holiday season has featured a seemingly endless parade of profit-eating promotions. But as the economy has become less gloomy, some retailers have tried to put the brakes on such offers this year. Sides predicts, however, that promotions will be as plentiful as ever this year, and will probably start early.
“We learned our lesson a couple of years ago, in that we had some really bad weather just before the holidays,” Sides said. “So I think that’s also what pushed folks to driving promotions earlier in the cycle.”
